Authors:
Rémy Poncet, Jean Hivert, Christian Fontaine, Frédéric
Picot, Ehoarn Bidault
Title:
Biostatistical and molecular approaches using open-access
data to address saprotrophic fungi distribution at a global scale: a
case study using Hexagonia hydnoides (Polyporaceae) as a model
species
Keywords:
Species Distribution Models, Monte Carlo Simulation,
Bayesian Molecular Clock, Biogeography, Cryptogams, Polyporaceae.
Abstract:
Species distribution models (SDM), ecological closeness
calculation, and divergence time estimation based on molecular clock are
powerful approaches that benefit from a strong experimental background
and have proven to be useful to cope with subjects like biogeography,
evolutionary history, or biodiversity conservation. However, combining
the three approaches to address species distribution at a global scale
and drivers that shape it remains a study field yet poorly developed. A
three steps process fully based on open-access data and open-source
software, mixing biostatistical (SDM and ecological closeness
calculation) and molecular approaches (divergence time estimation), was
developed to address common questions regarding saprotrophic fungi
distribution. The process is reported in this paper using Hexagonia
hydnoides (Sw.) M. Fidalgo as a model species. This well-known polypore
exhibits an unclear distribution pattern with some strongly disconnected
populations and has a well-documented dependence to host tree species,
and available open-access molecular data. The ensemble SDM were
performed using two algorithms: Random Forest and MaxEnt. The ecological
closeness calculation was computed thanks to a Monte Carlo simulation.
The divergence time estimation was based on a bayesian molecular clock
approach using three molecular datasets: 28S, ITS1+5.8S+ITS2+LSU, and
SSU+ITS1+5.8S+ITS2+LSU, and fossils calibration points. Divergence time
estimations were consistent with previous works, notably for the most
recent taxa (Polyporales, Polyporaceae, and Trametes), which divergence
time was recently estimated with the whole genome. Results suggested
that H. hydnoides is a Neotropical species that have evolved rather
recently (30.37±2.29 million years ago) during the Eocene period. It
seems to be no climatic nor edaphic limitation to its presence in the
whole pantropical area, suggesting that populations strongly
disconnected from its originating area (i.e. in Eastern Africa) are
certainly due to rare long-distance dispersal events and that this
species has de facto limited long-distance dispersal abilities.
